content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <rdf:RDF xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:syn="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/syndication/" xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/">             <channel rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/search_rss">   <title>Environmental Information Data Centre</title>   <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk</link>    <description>                  These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 5.            </description>            <image rdf:resource="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/logo.png"/>    <items>     <rdf:Seq>                <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/a5093d15-be48-48de-b8fd-41f573cf2b10"/>                       <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/ca6752ed-3a22-4790-a86d-afadaedda082"/>                       <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/37a503da-d75c-4d72-8e8b-b11c2fdc7d92"/>                       <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/0023bd6e-4dd7-462c-aacf-f13083b054ab"/>                       <rdf:li rdf:resource="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/86cd1a60-64f1-4087-a9f1-a3d8a9f8f535"/>            </rdf:Seq>   </items>  </channel>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/a5093d15-be48-48de-b8fd-41f573cf2b10">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - farm management data</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/a5093d15-be48-48de-b8fd-41f573cf2b10</link>     <description>This dataset consists of farm management data which includes crop drilling dates and herbicide application dates. The data relate to arable fields in which a range of ecological measurements were collected, including species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. Each field was sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional crops, either Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape or Winter-sown oilseed Rape. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). Data were collected for four crops overall (Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape and Winter-sown oilseed Rape).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Species distribution</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>agro-ecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable farming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>environmental impact</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>weeds</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>seedbank</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>invertebrates</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>functional groups</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>genetically modified herbicide-tolerant crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>sugar beet</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>maize</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>oilseed rape</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>trophic interactions</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Project C01732</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biodiversity Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2012-02-27T10:10:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/ca6752ed-3a22-4790-a86d-afadaedda082">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - maize</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/ca6752ed-3a22-4790-a86d-afadaedda082</link>     <description>This dataset consists of a range of ecological measurements collected from a set of arable fields, each sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional maize crops. Measurements include species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). Data were collected for four crops overall (Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape and Winter-sown oilseed Rape).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Species distribution</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>agro-ecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable farming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>environmental impact</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>weeds</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>seedbank</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>invertebrates</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>functional groups</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>genetically modified herbicide-tolerant crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>sugar beet</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>maize</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>oilseed rape</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>trophic interactions</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Project C01732</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biodiversity Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2012-02-27T10:10:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/37a503da-d75c-4d72-8e8b-b11c2fdc7d92">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - winter oilseed rape</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/37a503da-d75c-4d72-8e8b-b11c2fdc7d92</link>     <description>This dataset consists of a range of ecological measurements collected from a set of arable fields, each sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional winter-sown oilseed rape crops. Measurements include species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). Data were collected for four crops overall (Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape and Winter-sown oilseed Rape).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Species distribution</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>agro-ecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable farming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>environmental impact</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>weeds</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>seedbank</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>invertebrates</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>functional groups</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>genetically modified herbicide-tolerant crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>sugar beet</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>maize</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>oilseed rape</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>trophic interactions</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Project C01732</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biodiversity Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2012-02-27T10:10:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/0023bd6e-4dd7-462c-aacf-f13083b054ab">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - spring oilseed rape</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/0023bd6e-4dd7-462c-aacf-f13083b054ab</link>     <description>This dataset consists of a range of ecological measurements collected from a set of arable fields, each sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional spring-sown oilseed rape crops. Measurements include species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). Data were collected for four crops overall (Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape and Winter-sown oilseed Rape).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Species distribution</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>agro-ecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable farming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>environmental impact</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>weeds</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>seedbank</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>invertebrates</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>functional groups</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>genetically modified herbicide-tolerant crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>sugar beet</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>maize</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>oilseed rape</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>trophic interactions</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Project C01732</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biodiversity Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2012-02-27T10:10:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     <item rdf:about="http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/86cd1a60-64f1-4087-a9f1-a3d8a9f8f535">     <title>Farm scale evaluations of herbicide tolerant genetically modified crops - beet</title>     <link>http://eidchub.ceh.ac.uk/metadata/86cd1a60-64f1-4087-a9f1-a3d8a9f8f535</link>     <description>This dataset consists of a range of ecological measurements collected from a set of arable fields, each sown with a combination of genetically modified and conventional beet crops. Measurements include species counts in the following areas: weed seedbank, vegetation in the crop, field edge vegetation, invertebrates. The data were collected as part of the Farm Scale Evaluations (FSEs), a four-year programme of research by independent researchers aimed at studying the effect that the management practices associated with Genetically Modified Herbicide Tolerant (GMHT) crops might have on farmland wildlife, when compared with weed control used with non-GM crops. Data were collected by a consortium of: the Institute of Terrestrial Ecology, ITE (now the Centre for Ecology and Hydrology, CEH), the Institute of Arable Crop Research (now Rothamstead Research, IACR) and the Scottish Crop Research Institute, SCRI (now the James Hutton Institute, JHI). Data were collected for four crops overall (Beet, Maize, Spring-sown Oilseed Rape and Winter-sown oilseed Rape).</description>          <dc:publisher>No publisher</dc:publisher>     <dc:creator>Claire Wood</dc:creator>     <dc:rights></dc:rights>            <dc:subject>Species distribution</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>agro-ecology</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable farming</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>Great Britain</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>England</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>soil</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>vegetation</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>environmental impact</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>biodiversity</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>weeds</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>arable</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>seedbank</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>invertebrates</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>functional groups</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>genetically modified herbicide-tolerant crops</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>sugar beet</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>maize</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>oilseed rape</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>trophic interactions</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Project C01732</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>CEH Biodiversity Programme</dc:subject>                 <dc:subject>NERC_DDC</dc:subject>          <dc:date>2012-02-27T10:10:00Z</dc:date>     <dc:type>EIDC Document Container</dc:type>   </item>     </rdf:RDF>
